cab.content: TRANSLATION.French Embassy,London.The French government have on various occasions indicated how desirable it would be that the United States government should co-operate in an examination of the reparation question.For that reason they regard with interest proposals which would enable a competent American citizen to take an active part in the work of the reparation commission, a procedure which is fore-shadowed in the declarations of Mr. Hughes.It goes without saying that the French govern-ment cannot but maintain the principle from which they have never departed, of upholding the provisions of the treaty of Versailles; that treaty' gives to the reparation commission certain well-defined powers which cannot in any way be modified. It would be absolutely inadmissible that the reparation commission should be deprived in any measure of its powers by any other body.me reparation commission is empowered by the treaty to "appoint all officers, agents and employees "etc. ...... to constitute committees whose membersB need not necessarily be members of the commission " and take all executive steps necessary for the "purpose of discharging its duties and to delegate "authority and discretion to officers, agents and "committees". (Paragraph 7 of Annex 2 to Part VIII)It It Is, therefore, within the powers of the reparation commission to designate, as Mr. Hughes has hiraself contemplated, experts whose assistance may- iappear necessary in order to obtain the information and particulars which it may require; it would he quite natural for,the commission with the approval of the U.S, government to call in one or more American experts whose assistance would undoubtedly be of the greatest value.This would not of course imply any abandonment by the reparation commission of its powers, which it would maintain integrally; the information, advice and opinion given to it would have no other object than that of adding to its knowledge in the seme way as that which it receives from its existing experts, the number of which it is at liberty to increase.On these conditions the government of the republic is ready to request the co-operation of the American government in the examination of the reparation problem and to agree that a joint repre-sentation to that effect be made at Washington.The experts of the reparation commission are already examining the Belgian memoranda which have been submitted to them. It will be open to them, as soon as passive resistance is actually at an end, which cannot be far distant, to undertake the study of the German proposals which the German government has already announced its intention of submitting.Albert Gate House, 26th October 1923.
